name: Accra
fun_fact: Fun fact: Auntie Muni's waakye stall in Labone has served former presidents, football stars, and countless Ghanaians from the same spot for decades - her waakye wrapped in banana leaves is so legendary that people line up before dawn, proving that Ghana's best food isn't always found in restaurants.

hero_dishes.name: Waakye
hero_dishes.description: Mix of beans and rice cooked together, served with gari (cassava powder), stewed meat or fish, kelewele (fried plantain), salad, and fiery shito sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Waakye (pronounced 'waa-che') is breakfast, lunch, and sometimes dinner in Accra. The most famous seller is Auntie Muni, whose stall attracts everyone from presidents to students. Traditionally wrapped in banana leaves, it's a complete meal in a package
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Auntie Muni's Waakye Stall (Labone area - legendary), Ayewamu by Jane (served in traditional Asanka bowls), Katawodieso

hero_dishes.name: Banku and Okro Soup
hero_dishes.description: Fermented corn and cassava dough formed into balls, served with okra soup or grilled tilapia - tangy, sour, and deeply satisfying
hero_dishes.origin_story: Banku is a staple across Ghana, but Accra's version is distinct. The fermentation gives it a characteristic sour taste that perfectly balances rich soups and grilled fish. At Katawodieso, this dish has been perfected over 25 years
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Chop Shop (famous for oilless banku and okro soup), Katawodieso (legendary street stall run by matriarch Ruby Duff-Tay)

hero_dishes.name: Fufu with Light Soup
hero_dishes.description: Pounded cassava and plantain formed into a smooth, stretchy dough, served with spicy tomato-based soup with goat or chicken
hero_dishes.origin_story: Fufu is eaten across West Africa, but the technique and consistency vary by region. In Ghana, it's pounded until silky smooth and eaten with your hands - you tear off a piece, dip it in soup, and swallow without chewing
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Azmera Restaurant (authentic with traditional decor), Buka Restaurant (fusion West African dishes since 2003)

hero_dishes.name: Jollof Rice
hero_dishes.description: Rice cooked in a spiced tomato sauce with vegetables and meat - the subject of intense West African debate about which country makes it best
hero_dishes.origin_story: Ghana vs Nigeria jollof is one of Africa's greatest culinary debates. Ghanaian jollof is known for being less oily and having a distinctive smokiness. Every cook has their secret ingredient
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Buka Restaurant (open-air setting, diverse West African selection), Ayewamu by Jane, Chop Shop

signature_drinks.name: Sobolo (Hibiscus Drink)
signature_drinks.description: Deep red drink made from hibiscus flowers, ginger, and pineapple - tart, refreshing, and served ice-cold
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed throughout the day, especially in Accra's heat. Street vendors sell it in plastic bags with straws. It's both refreshing and believed to have health benefits

signature_drinks.name: Palm Wine
signature_drinks.description: Naturally fermented sap from palm trees - sweet when fresh, more alcoholic and sour as it ferments
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Drunk fresh from calabashes, often in the afternoon. The sweet, milky liquid is best consumed the day it's tapped from the tree
